TITLE I--VIETNAM VETERANS MEMORIAL EDUCATION CENTER

SEC. 101. EDUCATION CENTER. Public Law 96-297, as amended (16 U.S.C. 431 note), is further amended by adding at the end thereof the following: ``sec. 6. education center. The Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund, Inc., is authorized to construct an education center at or near the Vietnam Veterans Memorial site, above or underground, to educate the public about the memorial. The center must be approved in accordance with the Commemorative Works Act and this section. The Commemorative Works Act applies to the education center near the Vietnam Veterans Memorial site, with exceptions for final approval and location requirements. The designation of the Reserve does not prevent approval of the center's site within the area. The education center near the Vietnam Veterans Memorial site is allowed within the designated area, with limitations on size to protect the memorial and surrounding open space. The education center near the Vietnam Veterans Memorial site will be constructed and landscaped in harmony with the memorial. It will be operated and maintained by the Secretary of the Interior, with funding provided by the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund, Inc. No Federal funds will be used for its planning, design, or construction. TITLE II--COMMEMORATIVE WORKS ACT AMENDMENTS

This title may be cited as the ``Commemorative Works Clarification and Revision Act of 2003''. Section 8908 of title 40, United States Code, is amended to establish a Reserve where no commemorative work shall be located. Clarifying and conforming amendments are also included. Section 8901(2) of title 40, United States Code is amended to include the encouragement of locating commemorative works within the urban fabric of the District of Columbia. Section 8902(a) defines a "commemorative work" as a permanent structure or landscape feature designed to memorialize individuals, groups, events, or elements of American history. The term 'sponsor' refers to a public agency or organization authorized by Congress to establish a commemorative work in the District of Columbia. The 'Reserve' is defined as the central axis of the Mall in Washington, D.C. and its environs include lands administered by the National Park Service and General Services Administration. The Reserve in Washington, D.C. includes areas administered by the Park Service and General Services Administration. Section 8903 of title 40, United States Code, is amended to specify work solely commemorating a limited military engagement and consultation with the National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission. The legislative authority for a commemorative work expires after seven years unless a construction permit is issued during that period. The legislative authority for a commemorative work can be extended for up to three years if final design approvals are obtained and 75 percent of the required funds have been raised. Upon expiration of the legislative authority, previous site and design approvals will also expire. The amendments to title 40, United States Code, establish the National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission and make changes to its membership and services. Additionally, section 8905 is amended regarding site and design approval for commemorative works. The National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission is amended to change membership and services. Section 8906 of title 40, United States Code, is also amended regarding criteria for construction permits. The National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission is amended to change membership and services. Criteria for construction permits are also amended to require a donation for perpetual maintenance and preservation of commemorative works. The funding for maintenance of commemorative works is primarily provided by the government, with less than 50 percent coming from private sources. Money deposited in the Treasury for maintenance by sponsors will be credited to separate accounts. Money provided by sponsors after 2003 will be credited to a separate account with the National Park Foundation, and can be made available for maintenance upon request. The Secretary or Administrator may request funds for maintenance of commemorative works from a separate account, not exceeding the total amount in the account. Funds provided will be available without further appropriation and remain available until expended. Amendments are made to Section 8908(a) of title 40, United States Code regarding the Secretary of the Interior or the Administrator of General Services. Amendments were made to Section 8908(a) of title 40, United States Code regarding maintenance of commemorative works in Washington, DC and Environs. SEC. 204. SITE AND DESIGN CRITERIA. Amendments to Section 8905 of title 40, United States Code include restrictions on locating museums in specific areas, development of site-specific guidelines by relevant commissions, and prohibition of acknowledging donor contributions in commemorative works. SEC. 205. NO EFFECT ON PREVIOUSLY APPROVED SITES. This title does not apply to commemorative works with approved sites before the enactment date. SEC. 206. NATIONAL PARK SERVICE REPORTS. Within six months of enactment, the Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with relevant commissions, must submit reports to Congress outlining plans to relocate National Park Service facilities, alter concession facilities, and limit merchandise sales in the Reserve to preserve its character. To preserve the character of the Reserve, the plan includes relocating existing sale or distribution structures and making other appropriate changes as needed. The Senate passed the bill on July 17, 2003.
